Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal: 1643087

Title: The 13th U.S. Korea Forum on Nanotechnology: Brain Inspired Computing and Nano Biomimetics for Energy & Water Sustainability- Sept.26-27,2016, Seoul Korea

PI: John Myung
Institution: Carnegie-Mellon University

Workshop Goal: To empower a common platform for scientists and engineers from both countries to accommodate urgent technology contribution brain-inspired computing and sustainable Water & Energy (WE) technology.

Nontechnical:
This Forum will actively encourage partnerships in nanotechnology for novel computer architecture and WE sustainability to have a huge impact in nanoscience, in addition to strengthening achievements and assessing the progress on recommendations made during the previous Forums. We also aim for exchanging young scientists, including the graduate students. The Forum proceedings and findings will be published on Carnegie Mellon website, and will be available to a broad audience in addition Published as a special issue journal publication.

Technical:
The novel contribution of this Forum is its ability to bring together a bi-national community of expert researchers and innovators who are working on the leading edge of brain-inspired computing and nano-biomimetics for sustainable WE. The proposed forum will simulate efforts to promote nanotechnology for the next generation by fully utilizing nanotechnology convergence and biomimetric methods. The outcome will lead to milestone for the timely technology. Along with the exchange of ideas among the leading scientists and engineers in nanotechnology area, this Forum will recommend timely new paradigms in this field for the next decade and promote collaborative initiatives between the two countries. Project Outcome Report:

The 13th U.S.-Korea Forum on Nanotechnology:

Brain-inspired Computing and Nano-Biomimetics for Energy & Water Sustainability

PI: Myung S. Jhon, Carnegie Mellon
 co-PI: Elias Towe, Carnegie Mellon
Ahmed Busnaina, Northeastern University
Mamadou Diallo, California Institute of Technology
 

We held the 13th nanotechnology Forum between the United States and Korea, to explore the topics on Brain-inspired (neuromorphic) computing and nano-biomimetics for Water & Energy (WE) sustainability, on September 26th & 27th, 2016 in Seoul, Korea.

The delegates at the 5th meeting of the U.S.-Korea Joint Committee on Scientific and Technological Cooperation (held on October 30th & 31st, 2002 in Seoul, Korea) agreed that the establishment of a U.S.-Korea Forum on Nanotechnology would be beneficial to enhance research collaboration in the field of nanotechnology among scientists and engineers from both countries. With this mission, we established the 1st U.S.-Korea Forum on nanotechnology, via National Science Foundation (NSF) funding, on October 14th-18th of 2003, in Seoul, Korea and continued for the past fourteen years. As the Korean counterpart to NSF, participation was overseen and funded by the Korea Ministry of Science, ICT and Future Planning.

During this Forum, we further empowered a common platform for scientists and engineers from both countries to accommodate urgent technology contribution on brain-inspired computing and WE sustainable technologies. Myung S. Jhon was the organizer in collaboration with Mamadou Diallo, Ahmed Busnaina, and Elias Towe and selected 10 senior presenters and 7 additional early-career participants as well as 11 senior presenters and 8 additional early-career participants from Korea participated. Please refer to our website for details http://www.cmu.edu/nanotechnology-forum/Forum_13/GeneralInfo.htm. We actively encouraged partnerships in nanotechnology for brain-inspired computer architecture and WE sustainability to generate huge impact in nanoscience, in addition to strengthening achievements and assessing the progress on recommendations made during the previous Forums. We aimed to provide maximum opportunities to young scientists, including the graduate students.

The intellectual Merits include:

i) Providing a common platform for bi-national community of expert researchers and innovators who are working on the leading edge of brain-inspired computing and WE sustainability, and ii) Simulating efforts to promote the above two areas for the next generation by fully utilizing nanotechnology convergence and biomimetric methods

The outcome for these timely technologies lead to the establishment of milestone for the nanotechnology convergence.

The Broader Impacts include:

i) This Forum brought new paradigms in these fields and promoted collaborative initiatives between the two countries as well as constructed policy roadmap of nanotechnology.

ii) This Forum contributed to society, the global environment and economy in a broader sense by focusing on timely emerging technologies.

iii) This Forum promoted the exchange of researchers between the two countries, especially strongly promoting the collaboration among early career scientists, including graduate students in contrast to the previous forums.
